title: Pope Francis Urges Ukraine to Have â€˜Courage of the White Flagâ€™ in Peace Talks
text:
Pope Francis made some of his strongest comments yet on Russiaâ€™s war against Ukraine in a newly released interview, declaring that Ukraine should be open to having the â€œcourage of the white flagâ€ as it contemplates peace negotiations.
The interview, with Swiss outlet RSI, took place last month and is scheduled to be released later this month, according to
Reuters, which obtained an early copy of the transcript.
A spokesperson for the Vatican said that Francis was mirroring the interviewerâ€™s language when he used the â€œwhite flagâ€ term, and that he was intending to push for a â€œstop to hostilities.â€
The question posed to Francis asked him whether Ukraine might legitimize Russiaâ€™s behavior if it were to concede defeat.
â€œIt is one interpretation, that is true,â€ the pope replied. â€œBut I think that the strongest one is the one who looks at the situation, thinks about the people and has the courage of the white flag, and negotiates.â€ He urged the countriesâ€™ leaders to turn to the international community for help facilitating the peace process.
â€œOne may feel shame,â€ he added, referring to negotiations. â€œBut how many dead will [the war] end up with? â€¦Do not be ashamed of negotiating before things get worse.â€
Francis said that he would be open to mediating himself. He previously dispatched a peace envoy to U.S., Russia, and Ukraine to try to expedite the process.
â€œThe word negotiate is a courageous word. When you see that you are defeated, that things are not going well, you have to have the courage to negotiate,â€ he reiterated.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is open to peace, he has indicated, provided that Russian forces leave Ukraine and its original borders are reinstated. Russian President Vladimir Putin has flatly rejected such demands.
Earlier this week, Turkish leader Recep Tayyip Erdogan offered to organize a peace summit, though it is not clear whether the proposal will gain traction.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Wintry weather creates higher risks for house fires
text:
54 minutes ago LA CROSSE (WKBT) -- The colder temps and dry air can increase chances of a house fire, according to the La Crosse Fire Dept.
They suggest practicing safety precautions like cleaning your chimney and checking it for wildlife to prevent from fires igniting in your home. They offered the following additional reminders:
- Check expirations dates on fire extinguishers, smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors. Most expire within 7-10 years, regardless of new batteries in them.
- If you have a real Christmas tree, water it every day and be leery of falling pine needles which indicates a dry tree.
- Keep an eye on all types of burning candles; Christmas Day is the biggest day for candle-related fires. Switching to battery operated candles is a safe alternative route.
- Use the three-foot rule when lighting a fireplace or turning on a space heater.
"Our favorite phrase around here is, "three feet from the heat." Whether that's a fireplace, whether it's a space heater, you want to make sure you're keeping that area clear," Molly McCormick, community risk educator of the La Crosse Fire Dept. "Make sure you turn it off each time you leave the room."
McCormick also suggests getting a space heater that automatically turns off if tipped over.
